So this game is entertaining at first. The combat seems somewhat fresh for the type of game that it is, the character progression feels real and interesting as well. The passive abilities leave much to be desired, but I understood what type of combat this game inspired, which would make activated abilities much harder to implement. I got that. The atmosphere, music, theme, character design and armor/weapons all look great. The engine is a bit wonky, but I've dealt with worse before. It is playable in that department. I will not critique its technical limitations.

Then comes PvP. This game throws you into it, and while that is not a problem, the entire point of this game is PvP. This means that any living person of another faction that you find is going to kill you, and likely chase you very far to get you (they barely have to if they just have a bow). Again, this is not in and of itself, by itself, an issue. It is the fact though that anyone who you run into, is typically level 100. This completely outclasses you. Okay. Fine. That's expected. Oh they looted my corpse. That's fine too. My gear is replacable, in fact, I like that aspect of the game. Gives weight to decisions and combat. I just need to get higher level, practice a bit more, and I'll then feel more impactful.

Nah.
Once I started to get into the level 70s, I was beginning to wonder when my damage would ever change numbers. I had seemginly, despite leveling and even using better weapons, not really doing the types of damage that is required to even kill anyone let alone actively PVP or participate in a meaningful way. An enemy approaches you, and typically finishes you in a couple swipes. Literally, everyone will be doing at least 200 to 300 damage per hit, and you are basically rarely ever 1v1ing anyone in this game. So you stand a literal, no chance. You see, this is fine. It raises concerns about what the end game really is about (which I suspect is just a gear race and grinding money to either buy or craft superior equipment) however. And considering that gear is actually difficult and annoying to obtain, the fact that it gets looted whenever you die in PvP is actually where this becomes slightly more aggrivating. You see, because gear and valuables are painful and boring and actually highly costly - people aren't really willing to actually "PvP." At any sign of trouble (their zerg is bigger than your zerg), people immediately hit their ESC button and tap the "Unstuck to Capital" button. This game's version of the Hearthstone in order to get you out of a sticky situation as long as you have the time. So what does this ever actually boil down to? Not that much PvP at all. You're mostly just (like with a lot of these siege oriented PvP games) trading castles and keeps and outposts. Defend? Why risk losing and losing costly gear? Just wait until they go away to take it back. What are they going to do? Take it back only for us to just take it back? A contested castle can switch hands at least a dozen times in a night, and at some point you're left wondering "Why am I doing this?"

Okay fine. I put my hands up. I said, look. I'm giving this game a try. It has a lot of elements that I enjoy, and I think that if I finally hit level 100 and begin digging into the gear and loot system things might start making sense. What do I do to level? Well don't believe what people tell you in chat. Arenas? I can't even seem to get them to pop a queue. Tourny? That happens a whopping 3 times a night, with a non-Loot siege afterwards which seems to be the most enjoyable thing in the game despite people rarely even succeeding the sieges. Capturing outposts and PvPing? Ehh. That *can* be good in theory, but you typically need a group and people that won't just tuck and run at the first sign of trouble. When you go on a tear through enemy land, there's really not a whole lot to go through and capture for even remotely reliable leveling. So what's left? Blue events on the map. Blue circles on the map appear that are akin to Public Quests from Warhammer Online. You get participation trophies for killing and contributing. However, nobody is ever doing these things - so you're left to your own devices. Great. This works for quite some time until I begin reaching the 60 - 70 range. Now the blue quests are getting methodically longer to reach my xp mark for the next level. Now I should go look into doing more difficult areas closer to more hotly contested pvp areas. Sounds fun actually. I trek my way over there, and begin fighting mobs. These blue circle events seem to have a different mechanic where npcs like to start swarming in from essentially a nether void. Because my gear and weapons are utter shit, fighting them is a nightmare, and having any more than one on you is just asking for death. To make matters worse, these things are typically located on mountain sides and the NPCs you're fighting are glitching and hovering through the ground and sliding towards you with entirely inconsistent movement. You work your way up to the final mob of the event, and he's surrounded by about 4 different guards. You manage to kill all of them miraculously and tediously by not aggroing all of them at the same time, and then you go up against the "Chieftan" to finish the quest. He blocks 3 out of 4 attacks, drains your stamina down, attacks and interrupts your attacks faster than you can even swing, and deals about 300 to 400 damage with medium/heavy armor that you'd find from just leveling (even if your guild is willing to give you good gear, have fun managing to keep your hands on it if you plan on doing any pvp).

This game is just quite frankly an unfinished mess, that solves none of the issues that these type of siege oriented pvp games have always had in the past. Nobody cares about defending anything, everyone will port out before you even realize what is happening and abandoning a castle to the enemies, and attacking keeps usually just consists of you and a zerg bashing a door down and killing some NPCs. Only to wake up the next day with the enemy having done the same thing. There's no point. Nobody is actually interested in pvping, and the gear grind is so real that dying is truly annoying especially since your entire power in the game is derived from your gear.

Just avoid. Even with all of the things I wish for in a game, this game just does not do any of it well.

Once upon a time a few people thought to themselves that it would be cool if Mount and Blade was multiplayer. They set out to make that experience a reality and I have to give credit to the devs for trying.

Some aspects of Gloria Victis are thoughtful and enjoyable, it's particularly interesting to see when and where a dev clearly took extra time and care when implementing certain features. I was excited to discover I could get worms and beetles from harvesting crops and that I could use them as bait to go catch different kinds of fish. Pretty thoughtful right? How about when it's raining I don't have to water crops or worry about them drying out? Seems like the right thought process, seems like someone understands the genre and with this intuition about the people behind the game I decided to bite. I bought the game for my family, loaded up on the in-game currency, and got ready to bring my crew into the game in style. I was excited for defending castles against other real players, I was excited to enjoy and explore a seemingly open and unique world. I was hopeful and ready to immerse myself in a world devoid of magic and the usual cookie cutter RPG clutter. I wanted to be the peasant that later becomes a worthy opponent and valuable ally in a medieval universe.

Then slowly came the realization that this game isn't for the players, it's for the devs. While there are certainly many behaviors in multiplayer games that the world would be better without, there is lurking behind the scenes a group of devs that treat this game like a sandbox for themselves to enjoy and dictate. I won't be shy to say that some of the passive aggressive behavior from the devs is actually more toxic than some of the worst players I've come across in any given multiplayer game. Someone can give you a hard time after beating you up in an in-game battle, but these devs will not only rip the game from your hands, they'll go out of their way to make you a liability to even speak to, even in other discord servers the devs don't own. I was cautioned by other vet players to not mention that I had been in the same channel as another previously banned player...on a separate discord server, in someone else's social space. I couldn't believe what I was hearing, the members of the discord server were afraid of having the devs take actions against THEM for even speaking with a banned player. I was new, I had no hand in any of the drama you can read about in other reviews but I can assure you, if you invest your time and build relationships in this game, it is subject to the devs leveraging it to dictate your life outside the game. That's not behavior I would like to support and for that and many other reasons I would recommend avoiding this game. Perhaps a more level headed and more competent group of developers can better represent the genre in the future, until then, this is not the game or social space for those looking for an open world medieval pvp experience.

All the social drama and developer's toxic behavior aside, the game engine itself is built on an old version of Unity. Like a castle built on sand, I don't see this game lasting long or ever living up to what it describes on it's store page. The gameplay is clunky and sluggish, the graphics are a little better than the original EverQuest and the combat is a battle of who can out glitch another player's glitch. The animations are inaccurate and show you one thing while something entirely different is happening in the code. I was taught by vets to ignore the animations and look for certain glitches, and to use those glitches to compete. This almost sounds like cheating and exploits right? Except these are all things the devs know, the devs use, and the devs ignore or call features....except when they don't like you.

For example, if I go die on a patch of my crops, the enemy can't loot me because their interact button would be to destroy my crops and not to loot my corpse. If my enemy is behind a tree or poll, I need to use a particular swing to attack THROUGH it. If I want to kill something without risking being hit, I can stand on certain hills at just the right height so all their attacks go through me and all my attacks hit. Swinging through walls or hiding behind invisible hitboxes that are throughout the map and part of nearly every collidable object is the normal and everyday experience in Gloria Victis. Want to hit that guy on the catapult that's about to throw a rock at your face? Too bad, you can see them, they're close enough you could even spit on them if it were real, but the hitbox is literally a giant rectangle around the entire model, they know this and will "hide" behind it, and that's normal here. The incompleteness and bugs in this game are toted as features or even praised as something charming to be embraced, as mentioned by a dev themself when saying to "embrace the clunk."

I gave this game and it's devs the benefit of every doubt, I trained, I learned, I gave this game time and plugged into the community. I participated in battles and sieges, I crafted, farmed, mined, and fished. I gave honest feedback, even spoke with a staff member for over an hour to share my experience and better understand the state of the game and where the devs were coming from. (You know who you are and I thank you for your time and wish you the best)

In the end it's a marathon of mundane grinding, typical one-sided faction warfare (most people join or switch to the winning nation), and an endless study of how to exploit an old and busted game engine while balancing your favor with the devs.

0 out of 10 and I regret every penny spent.

My skeptical friends ask me why do I believe Gloria Victis is a good game and why I think it will succeed. I think the answer hides behind all the hard work the developers are putting into the game, and how perseverant they are, gradually shaping a true MMORPG experience out of their game.

You need to know [b]that the development of GV started many years ago[/b] with a prototype game called "Ether Fields", made in custom engine from a couple of Polish guys who wanted to create a massive multiplayer online world set in a low-fantasy setting, inspired by western european folkore. The idea they tried to push consisted in a non-targeted combat, medieval warfare type of game, with classless progression, crafting and questing as core features.

Problems arose though, some of them were technical and others were communication related, because back then the game was barely translated. Every piece of information was scarce and it was scattered on their forums, mostly written in polish. There were issues with their engine which was lacking important systems that needed to be developed, with time and money that small independent studios like this one (at the time) often can't afford.

7 years have passed since I've read about the game for the first time. Many things happened in between, starting with the switch to Unity as the game engine of choice and the simultaneous rebrand to the current "Gloria Victis" as we know it today. From there, the development kept going forward, even after [b]a failed kickstarter back in 2012[/b], the developers kept working on the game, making slow but steady progress over the years, communicating now with their playerbase and overall improving the quality of their game and its systems.
Its main theme is composed by the man who wrote the score for The Witcher, a combat update released last year brought many so needed new animations for the characters and NPCs (thanks to an experienced animator who also worked on The Witcher; Polish guys being bros I guess), and the game core mechanics are all in place now. There's a game you can actually play and get looped into its systems. Not long ago Gloria Victis also suffered from serious connectivity problems where players had to experience constant lag and desyncs from the servers, which to be fair are still an issue sometimes, but then again it is far from what the player were experiencing just a couple of months ago.

Yes, the game is clunky and yes, there's still much to do in order to call it a finished product, but seeing how hard working the team is I'm confident we'll get there one day, and no, I'm not good at predictions. 

Honestly, I'm not going to explain to you all the features the game has to offer. Most of them are the standard stuff you'll find in any title of the same genre: linear questing, mob camps, resource nodes, markets and trading, crafting and so on... But I'd like to tell you what this game stands out for, aka, the things that should make you decide if this is the game for you.

[b]Endgame is mostly PvP[/b] if you don't want to be a crafter. There are 3 factions in the game, each one visually diverse, and you have to choose one, having the other 2 as enemies that you need to fight in order to control the many outposts and castles that are placed on the map. Having more of them turned to the color of your faction offers different bonuses to the player characters who belong to that faction. If you have ever played Daoc or if you have familiarity with the most recent WvW systems of Guild Wars 2 and ESO, you already know what you're getting into and where the enjoyment comes from in a game like this. The main difference from the last two games I mentioned tho, is that the PvP doesn't take place in an istanced map, separated from the main game, but it is instead the main component of the experience and it is played where all the other people are also crafting, questing and trading.

To support that game loop there's [b]a different kind of combat iteration[/b] from the standard MMO you have been accustomed to. Gloria Victis gives the players directional blocks and attacks, meaning that you can move your mouse in 4 different directions and your character will play an animation accordingly, similar to how the more famous Mount & Blade franchise work. It is fun, because combat despite not being "flashy" or offering active skills bound to an hotkey (not in the traditional sense), promotes smart play that rely on stats management, player skill and tactical manoeuvers. 

In the end it's a game about player interaction. GV should be played in a guild, and grouping is promoted by the game systems. For istance, there are various PvP events you can take part in that popup every day and that let you group with other players automatically if you decide to partecipate.

In my opinion, [b]if you like MMORPGs you should give the game a try[/b], or at least, you should put it in your wishlist, so that you can follow the development process and eventually hop in when you feel the game is ready to be played. Gloria Victis is being updated weekly and if you don't believe me I urge you to go looking at their news stream here on Steam, to see how in the two and a half years the game's been released there are already [b]150+ updates[/b], in the form of new content, patches, hotfixes or just diaries and notes that the devs write for the players to read.

To my friends who are skeptical I'd say that "time will tell", but also that by knowing something's history you'll have a good perspective on how things may turn out at the end. In Gloria Victis' case I guess it will translate in a very good MMO, maybe not the definitive one if such thing even exist, but definitely a good one.

[b]TL;DR: the game has the potential to become an unique MMO because of its setting and combat mechanics, plus it is being devolped by people who are showing they care, by doing good PR and releasing updates on a weekly basis.[/b]

55279887.developer_response:
Hello,

Thank you for your feedback. We’re reading all the reviews carefully in order to find aspects which can and should be improved, so Gloria Victis can simply become a better game. Some of the points you’ve made have been already addressed, while some others come from the very core design of the game, so I’d like to elaborate a bit about them:

1. Comparison to Mount and Blade, Chivarly and Mordhau (I believe you meant this title, since Mordheim is a turn-based game)

I’ll start from this point, as it determines many other aspects touched in your review. There is one but important difference between our game and the other games you’ve mentioned: while MnB, Chivalry and Mordhau (great games btw, we love them too!) are games with matchmaking battles of limited size, taking place in closed arenas, Gloria Victis is an open-world MMORPG. This single difference causes several consequences, but 2 most significant of them are:

A) Latency – when playing a matchmaking game, you’ll naturally look for a server with the lowest ping possible. Ideally, you won’t ever look at the servers with more than 50ms of ping. Gloria Victis, on the other hand, is an MMORPG with a single server per continent. It means that the game must be equally playable for both players having quick physical route to the server – which, in fact, can get close to 50ms – and the ones living far from the server’s location (which is, obviously, more frequent) so they have much higher ping.

B) Persistence and progression – as an MMORPG, Gloria Victis has many layers which normally don’t exist in the matchmaking games at all or are heavily limited, namely the player character’s progression, the entire economic layer and persistent world. I’ll explain it with more details in the next point, as it touches the same aspect:

2. Dependency on gear

First of all, Gloria Victis is an MMORPG, with the full RPG aspect and with no magic. It means that there is character progression, which still has to remain credible enough – so while most MMORPGs would involve magical features to let you boost your character, Gloria Victis puts more emphasis on the equipment selection. Moreover, the equipment itself is strongly tied to the player-driven economy, which is one of the core pillars of Gloria Victis as a MMORPG with persistent world.

However, the combat mechanics make selection of the equipment to counter the enemy’s armor more important than the item’s level on its own. As an example, even the best sword in-game will deal less damage to an enemy wearing full heavy armor than a starting bludgeoning weapon – which greatly increases the variety of viable builds and tactics, depending on the battle scenario. This mechanic, among many others, has been explained in details in this tutorial video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FOsaO3FtKC0&

2. Archery

Actually, the archers can be so effective in battles – especially when defending a castle – that many players have felt forced to wear heavy armor all the time, as many archers can focus on specific targets and hit them from large distance. For this reason, we’ve made some balance tweaks to achieve 2 goals: allow for more variety in viable builds for melee fighters and increase the meaning of skilled and devoted archers. For this reason, archers now have a number of dedicated passive abilities to choose from and each type of bow – regular, reflex and long bows – is viable against a given type of armor.

3. Friendly Fire

This topic has been discussed many times, so let’s make a short summary. We’ve already tried friendly fire turned on all the time, but it caused problems in dense battles, like in shieldwall formation which is a natural choice in castle sieges. A single player could simply get into a group of enemies who couldn’t even hit him. Anyway, we have plans to improve the group vs group combat, i.e. we’re now working on the diminishing number of targets being hit for cleave effect when hitting through allies.

4. Slowing down

Actually, there is a pretty simple mechanic allowing you to slow down the enemy: legshot with full power. This mechanic is in the game for pretty long time already.

5. Spinning

We are carefully analysing why even the players would like to spin more than they would naturally and constantly improve the combat mechanics. For instance, the recent updates introduced the rotation speed clamp for kicking (such a clamp has already been present for any other combat situation). There are also the improved blocking markers which let the players set custom colors for them so they don’t blend with the background, and thus spinning/changing the direction of rotation quickly to misguide the opponent is not a viable tactic anymore.

6. Community

Gloria Victis is a competitive game with persistent world – many players know each other well, so taunting is a natural thing. However, we keep doing all we can to make the game’s world a pleasant place. We have expanded our moderation staff some time ago which really helped improve the players behaviors and reduce the overall toxicity. Of course, being a really small independent development team, we’re not able to watch the in-game chat all the time, but there’s an in-game player reporting system which has proven many times to be very effective. If you’d ever experience any problems with some other player’s behavior, please simply report it using the in-game tool which can be accessed in the ESC menu – our moderation staff reads all the reports daily.

And the last thing: Gloria Victis is still in development. It’s not feature-complete yet and some mechanics will naturally change and improve over-time, according to the current needs of our Community. The point is that we’re actively talking to our players and listening to their suggestions, at the same time updating the game every single week. For this reason I hope that you’ll give us another chance someday and find the game more enjoyable, and fun to play.

Have a great day!

Best regards,
Bartold

Hello there, person who is wondering about this title. Let's get started!

I highly recommend picking up Gloria Victis. If you are able to catch it during a sale that's a great time to do it, but if not, the game is easily worth the normal $20 price. 

My brother and I started playing about 4 months ago, and quickly fell in with a great guild on NA - Ismir, Aesir. They helped train us up, and generally showed us the ropes. You probably don't care too much about the details of my experience, so here is a list of reasons why I have recommended the game to friends.

The World:
One of the first things you are likely to notice is the sweeping vistas that lay before you while you're first exploring the world. Even after playing the game for several months, I still take a few moments to stop and appreciate a sunrise or sunset in game. The lighting is beautiful.

Leveling:
It is very easy to level in Gloria Victis. The most efficient way is probably to use the arena and wait until the last twenty levels or so to complete the starter quests. This is also an excellent way to learn the combat system - though it may be more punishing than many would be willing to endure. If you run the initial quest line, however, you will end around level 30'ish. By completing other world events (blue circles on your map) and participating in PvP even a casual player will likely be level 100 within a week.

Gear:
Gear is easily attainable on the market, or from the corpses of your enemies. On the flip side, the loot system prevents you from losing more than two or three items in the event that you are the corpse, rather than the looter. 

Combat:
There are opportunities here and there, but generally I find the combat to be responsive, and skill-based. I have watched guild-mates who are excellent duelists run around on a low level alt and kill fully geared, level 100 opponents. If you are like me and are losing some of those "twitch" reflexes in your old age, you can still find ways to be successful. Timing, knowing how and when to feint,  when to block or drop your block, etc., all make a big difference. In extreme cases (like me - I suck), become the best damn medic you can be by rezz'ing people, filling gaps in a shield wall, or stabbing past the shield wall with a spear. 

PvP:
I know, I already wrote a little about the combat, but this part is the "context" of that combat. I grew up playing Ultima Online, and later played Dark Age of Camelot for about 8 years. Gloria Victis doesn't have everything I loved about those games, but it's closer than many others have been. 

There are three nations competing for territory. The map has an outer ring of castles (large flags) and resources (small flags), most of which serve as places to gather, farm, or manufacture goods. The ones closest to enemy borders tend to "flip" frequently. When you're looking for PvP action, you can usually find some around these areas. The other reason to capture these is that there are 3 "temples" where additional gear (weapons) can be obtained, and which have excellent resource nodes. Beyond the gear and resources, owning certain temples appears to annoy the other nations quite nicely. The castles act as a sort of buffer for those temples, because cutting off their supply lines by capturing the surrounding castles (visible on the map) will prevent guards from spawning at the temples. The most frequent PvP action (and non-loot siege events) occur in this outer ring. 

The middle of the map is where things get to be much more fun. Guilds can claim castles in this territory, which offers some tangible benefits like additional resource nodes, crafting opportunities, etc. For my purposes, having a guild castle also provides you with another location to teleport to for certain world events, and again, owning one seems to generally annoy  your enemy nations. These castles usually flip far less frequently. In order to siege, or be sieged, the castle has to be "tokened" by an enemy guild, which allows you several hours to communicate with guildmates and arrange your defense efforts. It is a pretty common practice for other players from the same nation (but not the same guild) to assist in those defenses. 

Unfortunately, there are times when no attack comes - a strategy used by some over a period of weeks to reduce the number of defenders. On the plus side, that's a great opportunity to read a book/forum for an hour, or hang out in comms with some people from your nation who you might not otherwise get to know. When attackers do show up, the fights are intense, and full of loot.

Catapults have recently been added, and it has added yet another dynamic to sieges which can aid both attackers and defenders. Figuring out how best to use these has been a lot of fun, and is still a work in progress for the people I run with.

Farming/Crafting:
This is a thing in the game. People tell me they like it. Sometimes when I want to kill enemies, someone will say, "One second, it's raining - I need to plant my crops." I don't farm/craft, so that's all I can say.

The People:
MMOs are, in my experience, very much what you make of them. A big part of that is finding a decent group of people to spend your in-game time with. Find yourself a group like that; a group you can have fun with and that can guide you through some of the experiences in-game that are not fully explained. Your experience will be better for it, and the game will be better for having more people like that. There are some trolls, just like every game, but it is my experience that they are a minority. Also, muting people is very easy should the need arise.

I hope you found that useful, and I hope to see you in-game, either as an ally or a loot bag! :)

~ Cir

Each round of changes improves the game. Over the past few months we've seen the safe zone for new players to learn and gain an understanding on the game grow. Good graphics

*1.0/Full Release Update*

I wanted to update this review now that the game is (allegedly) fully released, and I'm disappointed to find that the 'No' is only solidified. There are a few different reasons for this, but by and large it's clear Gloria Victis was not prepared for full release. 

As other reviews have made clear, the 'launch' has been plagued by various issues. It's not an exaggeration when they state that they are unable to play the game; progressing past Steam Authorization is a crapshoot, connecting to the servers is a crapshoot, your characters loading is a crapshoot, etc. Crashes are common, and game mechanics have to be disabled to mitigate strain on the database (more on this later). For this reason alone, I wholeheartedly recommend waiting until the dust has settled and waiting for things to stabilize before exploring what Gloria Victis has to offer.

Design decisions have only gotten more questionable. Shortly before the 1.0 Release, the game's main draw (State of War, a feature that permitted open-world PvP to contest semi-permanent ownership over ingame locations) was removed. It was a running joke that the majority of Early Access players would only log on for these events because it was the only (almost) guaranteed good content. Black Eye Games is allegedly reworking this feature, but removing the main feature of the game right before 1.0 Release is objectively a backwards decision. If reworking the feature is the intention, why not release 1.0 when this feature is re-implemented? Many of the executive decisions here don't add up. 

Following the game's 'official' release, things have been shaky. First, players encountered a 'Firewall Issue' that prevented them from connecting to the game servers (it became apparent that the Firewall Error text was placeholder text and had nothing to do with an actual firewall; nor was this a player issue). Most recently, the game is (allegedly) subject to DDOS attacks that are now responsible for most (if not all) of the issues players are encountering. I personally find this skeptical, but regardless - it's clear that the infrastructure is unable to handle the strain that 1.0 has placed upon it. Database issues are common, and the necessity of disabling the more demanding game mechanics to prevent overloading the databases only reinforces the hardware suspicions. 

It's unfortunate to see Gloria Victis mismanaged like this. Underneath all the nonsense, there is a neat little game there. As time goes on, the game is only further buried underneath both inexperience and preventable decisions. In its current state (and sadly, for the foreseeable future), Gloria Victis is only a harder pass. The indie studio/small dev excuse was worn out long ago.

I then spent the next few hours continuously playing, leveling, crafting, learning the game, questing - I enjoyed myself a lot, enough so that I took no breaks for nearly 6 hours!

At this point I decided to purchase the game for my wife, bring her along, this was when things started going down hill...

Now I had someone else with me, we started having to play differently, more tactically etc because of level gaps.

We started noticing what seemed like mini-zones where mobs would disappear for a while then randomly reappear.

When another character was with me, I started noticing how other players animations are all wrong, as if while the game is at 60FPS, the character animations are more like 18 - 24 fps, really jarring when getting immersed into an rpg.

There seems to be some significant lag spikes, now I don't know if the team is struggling for server hardware (with a game like this they could likely find GSP's that would actually sponsor their project and provide heavily discounted or free hardware if that was the case) or if their networking code is severely lacking (from the perspective of someone who spent 8 years writing networking code for popular MMO emulators, it's easy to get it wrong - But not too hard once you get the hang of it, good luck if it's this, it'll come), or if there main server game loop is just single threaded so every time something major happens, the whole thing grinds to a halt - Only the developers know the answer to that.

Overall I'd say the game is fun, but for 2 years work, I feel that this game will be massively outdated or supersceded by a rival long before it reaches the point it's polished enough to provide a proper immersive rpg feel.
